title: Opinion: In loss to New Orleans Saints, Chicago Bears show they are what they said they weren't
text:
CLOSE Check out some early NFL headlines. USA TODAY

CHICAGO -- The Chicago Bears are not salvageable. Not this season, anyway.

What else to think after the abysmal performance in the 36-25 loss to the New Orleans Saints on Sunday? The Bears managed all of 252 yards, the bulk of which came in the fourth quarter when the game was out of hand. Of Chicago’s seven running plays, two were fumbles. Mitchell Trubisky was only an interception away from filling up his bingo card – skipping the ball into the dirt, overthrowing his receivers and getting sacked after holding onto the ball too long.

And to think, this was the Bears with an extra week to prepare.

After the season-opening loss to the Green Bay Packers, coach Matt Nagy promised that the anemic offensive showing wasn’t reflective of who his team is. Trubisky called the ineptitude uncharacteristic. Everyone in the locker room insisted the Bears would not take the step back many were predicting after last year’s NFC North title.

It was a long Sunday for quarterback Mitchell Trubisky and the Bears. (Photo: Matt Marton, USA TODAY Sports)

But five games later, the hard truth is that Chicago is a deeply flawed team that, at 3-3, will struggle to crack .500.

Trubisky’s woes can’t be blamed on the injury to his non-throwing shoulder that kept him out of the loss to the Oakland Raiders in London two weeks ago. He simply is overmatched, and the mistakes he’s making are the same ones he was making last year. There has been no sign of growth, no indication he can be the franchise quarterback the Bears envisioned when they traded up to take him with the No. 2 pick in the 2017 draft.

But this is not all on Trubisky’s shoulders. The offensive line is porous, and its shortcomings go far beyond the newly departed Kyle Long. While the Saints gave Teddy Bridgewater so much time to throw he could have run to the concession stand for a hot dog, Trubisky rarely has the luxury of having time to throw.

(Granted, when he does, he squanders it. But still …)

Matt Nagy isn’t doing his offense any favors with his game plan, either. This is the NFL, not the WAC, and a run game is a necessity.

Running the ball, especially on first down, keeps defenses honest and eventually opens things up for the passing game. It also would take some of the pressure off Trubisky. Nagy has acknowledged knowing all of this and has promised to find more of a balance.

Yet week after week, Tarik Cohen, Mike Davis and David Montgomery might as well be on milk cartons for as much as they’re seen.

The Bears have one of the nastiest defenses in the NFL. But counting on Khalil Mack and Co. to bail the offense out, with either points or turnovers, is not a sustainable plan. Just how fragile it is was evident Sunday, when Chicago clearly felt the absence of Akiem Hicks.

The Saints were missing Drew Brees, Alvin Kamara and Jared Cook. Yet without Hicks, who is on injured reserve with an elbow injury, the Bears were pushed around and knocked over. At one point near the end of the third quarter, Latavius Murray had 86 yards rushing – three more than the entire Bears offense had mustered.

New Orleans’ 36 points were the most allowed by the Bears this season. The 11-point loss, which made the game seem much closer than it was, was the largest of the year, too.

Worst of all, Chicago’s schedule gets markedly harder from here. The Bears still have to play both Los Angeles teams and the Kansas City Chiefs, as well as four NFC North games – one each against Green Bay and Minnesota, and two against Detroit.

Look at the remaining schedule, and the only “gimme” game left might be the New York Giants.

The Bears began the season full of hype and bluster. Turns out, they were off the mark on that, too.
